STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 9, 2020
Amy Bailey
Pathways of Arbor Circle
412 Century Lane
Holland, MI 49423
RE: License #: CB700201042
Pathways of Arbor Circle
412 Century Lane
Holland, MI 49423
Dear Ms. Bailey:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
May 19-29, 2020. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It
should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of
the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of
this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616)552-3662.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 200
121 Franklin Street SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
(269) 330-7082
enclosure
2

DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12311 Foster parent/agency agreement.
(3) An agency shall document review of the foster
parent/agency agreement with the foster family at least
annually and, when needed, develop a new agreement.
One of six foster home files reviewed did not contain a copy of an annual foster
parent/agency agreement.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by
another agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record
containing all of the following documents:
(d) A copy of the current reevaluation with written
endorsement by the borrowing agency that the evaluation
is acceptable.
One of three borrowed home files reviewed contained the required reevaluation
report; however, the report was not endorsed by the borrowing agency.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(c) Provide ta copy of the report to any social service
worker that has children placed in the home.
Two of two special evaluation report files reviewed did not contain information
indicating that the reports were provided to the applicable workers.
R 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(b), shall include all of the following
information:
(e) A plan which includes any changes made since the
previous plan and which has the content specified in R
400.12419.
Two of eight Open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
the Updated Service Plan was completed as required. This involved the Updated
4

Service Plan missing updated placement information on three of twenty-five Updated
Service Plans reviewed.
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and
parenting time that contains, at a minimum, all of the
following:
(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster
child and the foster parent in the foster parent's home at
least once every month.
Two of eight Open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
the social service worker visited the child in care each month. This involved one
month without documentation in each of the two case files.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there
are no additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included
in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-09C FOSTER CARE ACTION SUMMARY REQUIREMENTS
Page 1-2
The Foster Care/Juvenile Justice (FC/JJ) Action Summary,
DHHS-69 (RFF 69), is used whenever there is “action” on a
case.
Which Cases/When:
All foster care cases where there is:
6. Case closing (if less than 30 days of completion of last
case service plan).
One of two Closed foster care case files reviewed did not have a completed DHHS-
69 Action Summary documented in the case file. The single DHHs-69 Action
Summary did not have an effective dated documented on the form.
This is a repeat violation cited in the 2019 Renewal licensing inspection report
at which time 3 of 6 files were found to be out of compliance and for which a
CAP was approved on July 3, 2019.
FOM 801 p. 11- Medical Passports
13
For each child in foster care the supervising agency must
maintain a medical passport containing all items listed in
MCL 722.954c.
5

Two of eight Open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
the agency met all of the requirements for the Medical Passport. The first case file
did not have documentation that the Medical Passport was provided to the caregiver
at time of placement or within 14-days following placement. The second case file
had the first documented Medical Passport occurring on 9/5/19 when the placement
took place on 6/26/19.
This is a repeat violation cited in the 2019 Renewal licensing inspection report
at which time 1 of 6 files were found to be out of compliance and for which a
CAP was approved on July 3, 2019.
FOM 722-08C Required Participation in Development - Parents and Youth
p. 2 over 14-Years Old
If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to sign the
PATP, foster care workers must identify, and document
additional action needed to secure the parent’s and/or
youth’s participation in service planning and compliance
with the PATP.
CI 17-096 Treatment Plan Signature Timeframes and
Documentation Requirements
All treatment plans with a report date of August 1, 2017, or
later must have signatures from all appropriate case
members within 30 days of the report date.
Five of eight Open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
the agency met the requirements for participation in the development of the service
plans. This involved two late parental signatures, two late caregiver signatures, four
missing parental signatures and one missing caregiver signatures. Overall, there
were seven service plans out of twenty-nine with issues around the required
signatures. Two of the parental and two caregiver signatures were reported to be
uploaded into the MiSACWIS system but under the wrong service plan document
tab.
This is a repeat violation cited in the 2019 Renewal licensing inspection report
at which time 1 of 15 service plans were found to be out of compliance and for
which a CAP was approved on July 3, 2019.
DHHS Policy Placement exception request (PER)
FOM 722.03-
page 14-16
PER completed when required and completed quarterly.
• Siblings placed apart
6

One of eight Open foster care case files reviewed required a PER for a sibling split
had the PER end on 4/6/20 but the sibling remained separated at the time of this
inspection.
DHHS Policy - Medicaid Card & DHHS-3762
FOM 801 - Page
18
Each child entering foster care shall be provided access to
medical care upon placement [i.e. The DHHS-3762, Consent
to Routine, Non-Surgical Medical Care and Emergency
Medical/Surgical Treatment card is to be given to the foster
parent at the time of placement.
One of eight Open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
the DHHS-3762 was provided to the caregiver at time of placement.
DHHS Policy CASEWORKER CONTACT WITH CAREGIVERS:
FOM 722-06H –
Page 7
The caseworker must have at least one face-to-face contact
in the caregiver’s home each calendar month. If there are
two caregivers, such as a primary and secondary caregiver,
the caseworker must have a face-to-face contact with the
secondary caregiver in the home at least once each
quarter.
Two of eight Open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
the caseworker met with the secondary caregiver each quarter. This involved two
undocumented quarters.
DHHS Policy TIMELY ENTRY OF CASEWORKER CONTACTS
FOM 722-06H p
15
All face-to-face contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS
within five business days of the contact.
Eight of eight Open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
each home visit entered into the MiSACWIS system was done as required. This
involved Seventy-three of ninety-five being entered timely for a rate of 77%
compliance.
7

DHHS Policy Family Team Meetings.
722-06B - page
2-6
Type Time Frame
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three business
days prior to a planned change of placement or no later
than three business days after an unplanned placement
change.
Note: Planned and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting, step-down
from a residential or hospital setting, return from AWOLP,
or request for change in foster home/relative placements.
Two of eight Open foster care case files reviewed did not have all of the
requirements met for the Family Team Meeting documented in the case file. This
involved one missing FTM for a replacement to the parental home and another FTM
occurring outside of the 30-day prior to the end of the service plan requirement.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
R 400.12321(1) One foster home renewal report indicated that the foster parent
reported where the hazardous materials (cleaning supplies) were kept in the home;
however it must be documented that the licensing worker viewed the storage to
verify compliance with agency policy.
R 400.12327(5)(c) & (6)(a) One special evaluation report reviewed indicated that the
allegations made against the foster home were found to be true, but no rule
violations were established due to the foster parent having a plan in place to make
sure it wouldn’t happen again. If allegations are found to be true a violation must be
established and a formal CAP put into place.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
Consultation was provided regarding double checking dates on documents as the
signature on one child adoption evaluation did not match the date on the report.
Additionally, one special evaluation file reviewed contained a letter stating that the
report was provided to the family. This letter was dated one day prior to the report
date.
8

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
The agency has submitted no acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
STAFF INTERVIEWS
The staff interviews conducted revealed that the workers and supervisors are
knowledgeable about the rules and policies and are updates on any changes by
their superiors and through department communications. They all feel well trained
and supported and had no concerns to report.
ANALYST FINDINGS
A DCWL Field Analyst visited the homes of three licensed foster families and three
unlicensed caregivers. The only concern reported was related to an unlicensed
relative caregiver stating to the analyst that her primary residence was her second
home, which was not listed in on any of the certification documents. This was
addressed with the Chief Administrator who had a staff member complete a home
visit to the residence on 3/3/2020 to assess the home. The Chief Administrator
reported that the second residence would be assessed annually.
Chief Administrator Assessment
A review of the Chief Administrator Annual Assessment completed by Amy Bailey on
was reviewed. The Chief Administrator indicated that there has been an increase in
staffing throughout the year, so there was a learning curve with some staff resulting
in missed timeframes related to some of the documentation. She reported that her
primary concerns were related to medical examinations and medical passport
documentation, which she was hoping to address by writing a grant for a dedicated
medical staff that would function as a health liaison.
9

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
June 8, 2020
________________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
June 8, 2020
________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
10
